subject: resource/Carter_G._Woodson
object: Carter Godwin Woodson (December 19, 1875 – April 3, 1950) was an African-American historian, author, journalist and the founder of the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. Woodson was one of the first scholars to study African-American history. A founder of The Journal of Negro History in 1915, Woodson has been cited as the father of black history. In February 1926 he announced the celebration of "Negro History Week", considered the precursor of Black History Month.

In February 1926 he announced the celebration of 'Negro History Week', considered the precursor of Black History Month.

Explanation:
The triple statement claims that Carter Godwin Woodson (December 19, 1875 – April 3, 1950) was an African-American historian, author, journalist and the founder of the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. 
Woodson was one of the first scholars to study African-American history. 
A founder of The Journal of Negro History in 1915, Woodson has been cited as the father of black history.
In February 1926 he launched the celebration of “Negro History Week”; it was the precursor of Black History Month.

This statement is supported by the documents provided:

* /Users/stefanomarchesin/Research/fshami/Rag/docs/dbpedia_7657/re-ranker-msmarco/74.txt
* /Users/stefanomarchesin/Research/fshami/Rag/docs/dbpedia_7657/re-ranker-msmarco/53.txt
* /Users/stefanomarchesin/Research/fshami/Rag/docs/dbpedia_7657/re-ranker-msmarco/25.txt
* /Users/stefanomarchesin/Research/fshami/Rag/docs/dbpedia_7657/re-ranker-msmarco/55.txt
* /Users/stefanomarchesin/Research/fshami/Rag/docs/dbpedia_7657/re-ranker-msmarco/39.txt

All of these documents mention Carter Godwin Woodson as an African-American historian, author, journalist and the founder of the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. They also confirm that he was one of the first scholars to study African-American history, founded The Journal of Negro History in 1915 (or 1916), and launched the celebration of "Negro History Week" in February 1926, which was a precursor to Black History Month.
